ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: What didn't I learn??! I learned everything about the whole VC process, understanding how startups grow from the investor perspective. I'm too lazy to write it all, but basically, this class will teach you EVERYTHING about VC you need to know. Also, it will help you determine if VC is the right path for you career wise.
Broad understanding of venture capital, including its successes, case studies, language/jargon, technicals, challenges, etc.

Learned a bunch about the world of venture capital. The course focused on the details of fund construction, the advising of companies, the ethics of venture capital, and case studies from a number of industry experts on their experiences.
I learned common VC terms, industry trends, the founder/VC perspectives of VC-backed companies, how to write an investment memo, and how to write an investment thesis

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Professor Torres is a huge strength. This class simply couldn't exist without him. His care, his insights, his connections to great speakers. Everything about the class is truly top notch. This is one of those rare classes where you're like wow, this class is truly exceptionally well taught. The readings are useful and not TOO long. The weekly discussion posts are perfect (they make me do the reading, but they're not hard and they're engaging). And the projects are useful for personal and career growth.

Weaknesses: I would put the final topic check-in back into the syllabus. I wish I settled on a topic for the final earlier.

Strengths: hearing directly from the practitioners (e.g., LPs, VCs, founders) was a highlight of the course; comprehensive and insightful readings; engaging activities and assignments with clear, reasonable expectations at all times. Weaknesses: sometimes, the "hype" felt a bit artificial (e.g., talking of 
"alumni" or "cohorts"), or at least bloated for the relative newness of the course at Yale College and minimal interaction with people/resources outside of the course in the given semester. Building that network for tangible results, without some of the fluff, would be great, and I appreciate Professor Torres's work on developing that on our campus!

I really enjoyed the guest speakers & the opportunity to hear from a number of VCs with a wide variety of investment experiences and strategies. Sometimes, I found that the course focused on more niche/granular parts of the industry (like fundraising types), but in general I loved the format of the course and all of the readings and assignments were super interesting.

Strengths: Prof Torres is incredibly available and puts his students first. Always willing to mentor everyone and take us on incredible field trips and create a community among his students
Weaknesses: At first I thought the course lacked VC finance but in the end I do not think adding more finance would be necessary or appropriate. I would swap out the climate week

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! A great course that attracts a lot of interesting students!

I couldn't recommend it highly enough. One of the single best classes I've taken at Yale. Take anything with Professor Torres, especially his VC class. HOWEVER< only take it if you're interested in VC. If you are not interested, don't take it. But if you're curious about VC, totally take it. You'll learn a ton from Professor Torres and your classmates.
Yes, without a doubt. This course changed my worldview and life direction.
yes, the best course ive taken at yale, hands down

Absolutely. Whether you are interested in venture/entrepreneurship from the perspective of a potential investor or founder, you will find what you are looking for in Funding It. Having the opportunity to learn about the industry in a more practical way is invaluable, and there are not (to my knowledge) any other classes at Yale that are taught in this way.
Absolutely. Best course at Yale for anyone interested in VC
